column1: Fistula: An artery in your forearm is sewn to a vein nearby.
- This allows needles to be inserted into the vein for dialysis treatment.
Central venous catheter: A soft plastic tube (catheter) is tunneled under your skin and placed in a vein in your neck, chest, or groin.
Taking care of the dressing (bandage): - If you have a graft or fistula, keep the dressing dry for the first 2 days.
Signs of infection are redness, swelling, soreness, pain, warmth, pus around the site, and fever.
- Change where the needle goes into your fistula or graft for each dialysis treatment.
- DO NOT let anyone take your blood pressure, start an IV (intravenous line), or draw blood from your access arm.
